author: Deleted User
content:

author: slodkokwasny.
content: Surely such a big project took / will take the necessary steps to test their app just as Uniswap&others did. The kiln testnet has been running for a while and there will be at least 10 weeks between Ropsten Merge > Mainnet. I'm not sure if there is anything to be done about some projects. The core devs can't infiltrate OpenSea team and force them to test their app. It's their own duty as a 13 billion project. And after all, the Merge doesn't really affect smart contracts, so there shouldn't be any issues anyway.

author: catwith1hat
content: I do believe some opcodes change in semantics, post-merge, such as "difficulty", see EIP-4399. If smart contracts use that opcode and the semantics change, there might be a problem. Any large smart contract ecosystem should test on Kiln.

author: syentist.
content: The Kiln testnet has been up since mid March. If (big if) the merge happens in mid Aug, that's 5 months - 150 days - for dapps to do their testing. That is the opposite of rushing. At this point, if any major dapp has not tested or prepared for the merge, you should take it up with them, not sabotage the entire Ethereum upgrades roadmap with further delays.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Given how many exchanges went down when open eth node had an issue during a fork I doubt it. Participation by dapps and exchanges in testnets is usually minimal to non existent. Plus you can’t really fully test when the spec is still changing and the nodes themselves aren’t finalized. I do hope everyone joins in by the final testnet.

author: jgm
content: One of the reasons to migrate all of the testnets is that it pretty much forces everyone to test.  As long as production dapps are present on at least one of the testnets they will get a run-out.
